title-group.article-title: A Spanning Approach for Estimating Divisional Cost of Capital

abstract.p: Two techniques for estimating risk-adjusted divisional hurdle rates are the analytical approach and the pure-play approach. The analytical approach relies upon theoretical linkages between observable accounting variables and the CAPM beta risk measure. The pure-play approach uses information about firms operating in the same line of business. This study develops a third technique, the spanning approach, which combines the advantages of the analytical and pure-play techniques while avoiding their implementation problems. The spanning approach for estimating divisional cost of capital revolves around the theoretical linkage between risky cash flows and asset returns. Implementation of the spanning approach requires development of systematic cash flow per share variability measures for a large sample of publicly traded firms and for a target asset such as a non-traded division. Spanning portfolios that replicate the covariance properties of the target asset's cash flows are then formed. In the absence of arbitrage, a portfolio that spans or mimics the target asset's systematic cash flow variability will have a required return identical to the required return of the non-traded target. To test the hypothesized linkage between risky cash flows and asset returns, we compare the return stream of a publicly traded firm to the return stream of its spanning portfolio, that is, a portfolio of publicly traded firms that spans or mimics the target asset's systematic cash flow variability. Results of tests on a sample of 436 firms indicate that the observable linkage between systematic cash flow variability and asset returns is useful to estimate the required return for a non-traded division. Application of the spanning approach to the divisions of Hershey Foods demonstrates its potential contribution. Practitioners and scholars alike should appreciate the evidence that the spanning approach provides about the linkage between risky cash flows and assets returns, which neither the analytical nor the pure-play approach directly addresses. In its recognition of this linkage, the spanning approach is particularly useful to practitioners making investment decisions for projects with business or financing risk characteristics that are different from those of the firm.
